node.title: Recall for ham and pepperoni balloons to 2.3 million pounds
node.description: Perdue Premium Meat Co. unit initially said 232,000 pounds sold nationwide could be contaminated with listeria.

node.title: Nassar abuse victims reach $380 million settlement
node.description: In addition to the payment, the organizations have also committed to safety reforms for future athletes.

node.title: Supreme Court allows New York vaccine mandate for health care workers
node.description: Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch dissented.

node.title: Philadelphia to check vaccine proof for bars and restaurants
node.description: Proof of vaccination is meant to decrease transmission while preventing complete shutdown of indoor dining, Mayor Jim Kenney said.

node.title: Insurer agrees to $800 million deal in Boy Scouts bankruptcy
node.description: Century Indemnity will contribute to fund for victims of child sexual abuse in return for release from liability.

node.title: Good for Business, but Bad for Birds and Horseshoe Crabs?
node.description: Some Coney Island residents are concerned that new ferry service would harm wildlife in Coney Island Creek Park.

node.title: 23-Year-Old Diagnosed With Cancer After Cough Mistaken for COVID
node.description: Caregiver Chloe Girardier was diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma five months after first seeking medical help.

node.title: What Amy Coney Barrett's Roe v. Wade Remarks Get Wrong About Adoption
node.description: Experts told Newsweek Barrett's remarks suggesting adoption alleviates the need for abortions ignores the burden of making a woman carry a pregnancy to term.

node.title: In Which U.S. States Are Face Masks Mandatory? New COVID Rules Explained
node.description: Face coverings are required in some U.S. states amid the ongoing threat of the Omicron variant, which has been reported across about half of the country.

node.title: Child Tax Credit 2021: Here's when the sixth check will deposit
node.description: The December 15 payment could be the last and final monthly check unless lawmakers renew the benefit for 60 million kids.

node.title: House January 6 panel recommends contempt charges vs. Mark Meadows
node.description: Startling text messages sent to the then-White House chief of staff during the insurrection were revealed during the committee's meeting.

node.title: At this tech company, workers vote on each other's pay raises
node.description: "There is no manager you have to suck up to," Expensify CEO David Barrett says. Even his comp is set democratically.

node.title: Tornado outbreak death toll in Kentucky rises to 74
node.description: Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear said his state suffered "the worst tornado event" in its history.

node.title: To Win M.L.S. Cup, New York City F.C. Played the Long Game
node.description: A team that once took the field behind big-name European imports embraced a new kind of star power en route to its first M.L.S. championship.

node.title: COVID Made Food Smell of Cat Urine, Taste Like Hot Bananas for Fox 2 Host Maurielle Lue
node.description: The news host has said she "felt like a shell of who I used to be" after experiencing long COVID symptoms.

node.title: Huge Cosmic Explosion Triggered by Birth of Black Hole or Neutron Star
node.description: The powerful explosive event, nicknamed "The Cow," was 100 times brighter and faster than a regular supernova.

node.title: Child's Arm Completely Torn Off in Harrowing Pit Bull Attack
node.description: Four-year-old Axel Foster's mother said: "He has undergone two surgeries and is still fighting not only to keep his arm but his life."

node.title: Nine-year-old killed in US storms, as death toll expected to rise
node.description: Primary school student Annistyn Rackley is one of 88 people confirmed dead after severe storms and tornadoes wreaked havoc across the United States, but authorities are expecting the death toll to rise as recovery workers search through debris across five states.

node.title: Pfizer says new trial data confirms high efficacy of its COVID antiviral pills
node.description: Early data from the company's experiments suggest the pill will be effective against all variants, including Omicron.

node.title: Pfizer says its Covid pill will protect against severe disease, even from Omicron.
node.description: The company said the pill, Paxlovid, reduced the risk of hospitalization and death by 89 percent if given within three days of the onset of symptoms.

node.title: A Portrait of Abortion
node.description: And the Supreme Court’s two very different paths.

node.title: Prince Andrew's Lawyer Says Accuser Was Above New York's Age of Consent
node.description: Prince Andrew's team says Virginia Giuffre was over the age of consent in New York when she says he sexually assault her while he was 41 and she was 17.

node.title: Mary Trump Says Her Uncle Was Disappointed Jan. 6 Riots 'Didn't Work That Day'
node.description: Ex-president's niece told MSNBC texts by Fox News hosts during Capitol riots suggested they knew "they were directly responsible" for violence.

node.title: The Welcome Return of the Run-In
node.description: Running into acquaintances used to be a routine annoyance. Now, it’s an unholy rush.

node.title: Dogecoin Price Skyrockets After Elon Musk Says Tesla Will Accept the Crypto for Merch
node.description: The SpaceX CEO made the announcement in the latest of his tweets about the meme cryptocurrency.

node.title: "Alarm bells" due to Arctic record 100 degree heat in Siberia: U.N.
node.description: The sweltering heat, on June 20, 2020 in the Russian town of Verkhoyansk, was the highest temperature ever recorded above the Arctic Circle, the World Meteorological Organization said.

node.title: Santa Claus’s Real Estate Is Booming
node.description: Is it any surprise that places where it’s ‘Christmas all the time’ have been attracting a record number of buyers during the pandemic?

node.title: Joe Biden Urged by Democrats to Keep Promise and Cancel Student Debt
node.description: In a letter to the president, Democrat senators warned that resuming federal student loan payments and collections on February 1 would hurt the economy.

node.title: Donald Trump's Financial Records May Finally Be Seen by House Committee
node.description: A three-judge panel may soon decide that the former president must turn over two years of financial documents.

node.title: U.S. and China Hold Military Talks on Avoiding 'Accidents' at Sea, in Air
node.description: The three-day virtual dialogue is only the third U.S.-China defense meeting to be publicized this year.
